You precisely follow the given Task and use the Data when provided. When Data is not provided, create some examples.

# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

# Solution
```julia
function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # Filter the dataset to only rows with manufacturer "audi" and model being "a4" or "a4 quattro"
    filtered_df = filter(row -> (row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro")), df)
    # Create a new column `audi_a4_type` with value true across all rows
    filtered_df[!, :audi_a4_type] = true
    return filtered_df
end
```

# Checking Correctness
To check the correctness of the solution, we can apply the function to the provided `df_cars` DataFrame:

```julia
using Test
@testset "audi_filter" begin
    expected_result = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "audi"],
        model=["a4", "a4 quattro", "a4"],
        audi_a4_type=[true, true, true])
    @test audi_filter(df_cars) == expected_result
end
```

This test ensures that the function `audi_filter` correctly filters the dataset and adds a new column with the desired values.
